abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Health Sector Support
            Project for Zambia was unsatisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was modest,
            and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            unsatisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that it is
            imperative that the Government commits to a reform program
            through effective advocacy to build a broad base of
            understanding and support for reform. Lack of attention to
            governance allows corruption to flourish and, poor
            governance undermines the efforts of many cooperating
            partners who need to make the case of continued support for
            health reform in Zambia. Procurement capacity should be
            strengthened. There is a widespread perception that the Bank
            disengaged itself from the health reform process in Zambia
            rather than working with other cooperating partners to
            sustain the reform effort during a period when it was under
            attack. Health sector reform is an intensive process and
            requires strong attention to human resource issues. Health
            staff need to have the right incentives, have access to
            continued professional development, and be retained in the
            health system in a productive manner. In high HIV prevalence
            situations, adequate attention needs to be given to protect
            health workers from occupational risks of HIV infection.
